column9: The Librotraficante Movement set out on a 1,000-mile+ caravan from Houston to Tucson, protesting against a 2010 Arizona law that banned Mexican American Studies from K-12 Tucson classrooms, codified as Arizona Revised Statues (A.R.S.) §15–112. The movement particularly objected against the effective banning of more than 80 books by and about Latinx people, which were taught as part of the curriculum. “When we heard that Tucson Unified School District administrators not only prohibited Mexican American Studies, but then walked into classrooms, and in front of young Latino students, during class time, removed and boxed up books by our most beloved authors," said Tony Diaz, one of the founders of the movement, "that was too much."

The Librotraficante Movement held many rallies and press conferences throughout the caravan, such as one that took place in front of the Alamo chapel. Many "contraband" authors—that is, authors whose works were effectively banned by A.R.S. §15–112—participated in the 2012 caravan, including Lorna Dee Cervantes, featured in this YouTube video, a highly influential Chicana literary figure also famous for her groundbreaking work in publishing, whose poetry was banned across five different anthologies.

The Librotraficante Movement also stocked and established a network of underground libraries that would circulate the 80 books effectively banned by the Arizona government. The inauguration of the first underground library at the San Antonio Southwest Workers Union took place on the first evening.
Denise Chavez hosting breakfast at her bookstore, Casa Camino Real Book Store & Art Gallery.
